{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3547414,"name":"6894 Lead prog/driver","username":"Mochatitan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mochatitan/{size}/237112_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T18:33:06.614Z","cooked":"

I am coding a command to auto-align, but it adds requirements of the swerve subsystem to do it, just encase of a defense bot, i want to be able to start to move and it will go back to using the defaultCommand for swerve? we are using yagsl btw.

pretty sure you can use .interrupt() but i’m not at a computer rn so i don’t know for sure

A few options:

  • If it’s being triggered using a button, use whileTrue instead of onTrue for your auto-align so that letting go of the button ends the command
  • interrupt the auto-align command by running another command that requires the drivetrain subsystem, then ends (e.g., something that does a runOnce)
  • if the auto-align command is using any other subsystems, run a command that requires any of them, which will cancel the auto-align (certain things can make this not work)
  • add a timeout or end condition
  • call cancel on the auto-align command, which requires some way to get access to the object itself

gotcha, it will be a button hold, but it will also start to extend our elevator, so i will probably make the end of the command run another command that brings the elavtor back in, maybe by adding a command to the commandSchedular in the end() method?

Another option, which is often what we do: Don’t take control from the drivers at all. Have your new command take both the joystick inputs and the closed loop, and add it together and feed it in the drive train. It’s not ideal for all implementations (full path planning), but for simple closed loops this enables the driver to both seamlessly start the process, and to “bias” it in case something went wrong on the field.
Then just put this new mixed command on a “while true” so it drops the “extra” input when you release the button.
